segments.text: Isn't that wonderful?
Okay, we're talking to William Gass here in St.
Louis.
Don't mind about it.
They're all your words.
And we're watching it.
There it goes.
Yeah, and I always wanted to have my own library.
I'm not a collector.
But you have 12,000 books somewhere.
Yeah, it's an accumulator.
An accumulator.
Okay.
It's, I don't think one would find many

really rare or ununique or something books in all of this I mean a few but nothing really on the whole I just have gotten out to a place where I really have a working library I'm at home with my books and almost everything that I need is at hand and that is just my idea of total you know luxury and
The book I just finished, which is coming out this fall, and the title is Every Book It's Reader.
The Power of the Printed Word to Stir the World, Not to Change the World.
That's a little, that's reaching a bit too much.
But books that make things happen.
But one of the goals for me in this book was to be able to try and do it with all the books that were available and at hand, within reach, in my home.
After all these years of putting together not 20,000 books, but let's say 10,000 or 15,000 books, the Lord knows how many there are.

But to try at this point in my life to use what I had, and especially the literary biographies and the works of criticism, your Wilker book, for instance, which is a few years old, and I said, finally, I have a chance to use it, you know?
Oh, yeah.
And it was wonderful.
It was just wonderful to finally say, oh, I've got a book on that.
Oh, yeah.
To just follow... Oh, yeah.
That's all...
I mean, um, I have, I just finished, I've been doing a series of pieces for Harper's, and I just finished one on Nietzsche.
Uh, well, when I wanted to write on Nietzsche, I just went to the basement.
We have stacks in the basement and stacks in the first floor and all the second floor and so forth.
And so I just went and gathered up an armload of books, you know, and took them up there, and I had all that I needed.
And that kind of thing, when I did the piece on Rabelais, I was a little lucky.
We have what we call various rooms, the French room, the German room.
Really?
Mary's favorite room is the French room, which is just French literature.
German is in our bedroom.
And I just...
went there and I happened to have an old, beat-up, terrible copy.
The pages are all brittle and brown.
It's just awfully cheap piece of stuff.
I think I bought it in a little bookstore in Paris forever ago and never used it.
And my French isn't all that great, but I wanted to look at the original.
because these were translations of Gargantua and Pettigrew.
And I—this book happened to be an annotated version with notations for each of the changes and each of the editions.
Really?
And it was perfect for me, you know.
And it was this book, which I never thought I would ever use.
I had a book that I—Mary says, what do you say to me?
book on histology?
I mean, what is it?
Well, it came in handy from my novel, The Tunnel.
I used it for diagrams and all kinds of stuff, and never thought I'd, you know.
So my belief is every book is, you know,
a sacred object, and it's going to—you never know, and it's going to leap into your heart.
Every book gets reader.
If only one person reads the book through the course of its existence, it serves its function, hasn't it?
Oh, help yourself.
I'll just have a little coffee for a bit.
I don't know what these things are.
When you were writing The Tunnel, and you had this book on histology, is it?
Yes.
Which came first, the need for the book on histology, or the fact that you had it?
No, I just had it.
I just had this, I saw this book, and of course I'm great on cheap, because we don't have that much money to buy books, so we have to buy them when they don't cost anything.
And I was fascinated by the drawings in it.
And then I just put it on the shelf, and it sat there for twenty years, at least.
And then I wanted an image for the final page of the novel, and I thought, anus, that's what I need.
And there was, in that book, a beautiful drawing which I could reproduce.
You never know.
It came right out of your... I wish I'd had this anecdote two months ago, let me tell you.
It's the perfect illustration of exactly the kind of thing I'm looking for is how your books really energize your own creative... your books.
Oh, yeah.
Well, and they give you all kinds of ideas, like...
We emptied out at one time, many years ago again, an attic that belonged to my wife's grandparents.
And it was sets of the new century, of Harper's going back to 1865, 78, but also some that included Henry James' pieces and things like that.
And I've been thinking about and I'm going to do a piece on a piece of fiction that works out of the ads in these old magazines because they are a story all by themselves.
And so I've been taking a few notes and working up.
So here are these bunch of old magazines which are now going to do something.
You know, you never know what
what will give you an idea.
Is it fair to say that a good deal of your creative process emerges from your reading?
Almost all of it.
Really?
Yeah.
In the tunnel I used a little, some material, not much, that's autobiographical.
But, for instance, people constantly do this with me.
They say, gee, you must know a lot about gardening.
My wife is a wonderful gardener, but because of all these plants and a whole, this paragraph about weeds and stuff.
And I said, no, I'm just collecting it.
Gardening catalogs.
I collect book catalogs, and it's amazing.
And people are, they say, what do you find out about this?
And I say, read the bookseller's catalogs.
Read the auction catalog.

you hire all of these bibliographers and these researchers to get all this detail and the history of the book the provenance the ownership it's amazing the detail that you can get from catalogs that you can't get i mean that's where the professionals are applying their trade that's right preparation of these so it's not only the reading of great creative works but also the reading of

stand near anything or anything but i also providence my providence is again because of fatigue is i buy a lot of books we're going to have our big cultural event in st louis in a few days the book fair and there'll be a million books and it's almost literature oh it's a great thing i mean it is wonderful uh and you do get
great bargains now and then.

I mean, I picked up a copy of Joseph in Egypt, and I was looking at it, and it was a buck, and then I saw that it was signed to his hostess when Thomas Mann came through in the thirties, and I bought this book.
It's one of my goodies in my library.
Hemingway, similarly.
pick up Paul Valery in French here.
Wouldn't you love to know where they came from?
Yes.
How things wash up.
I remember buying a copy of Santillana's The Sense of Beauty in a goodwill over here someplace for a quarter, and I thought, how did it wash up on these shores?
You know, that's exactly the image that Charles Lamb uses.
referring to Coleridge, how he takes books and he never returns them.
But he said, for just as many books as he takes, he brings in like a tiger.
Oh, I see.
So just as many wonderful things as you lose, he will bring books that he brought from someplace else and he'll deposit them.
And of course, Coleridge was the great annotator of books as well.
Oh, that's right.
And I have a little riff on him in my new book, one of the things that he wrote.
I think it's Princeton.
It's published in eight volumes of his Marginalia.
Oh, there's that book that came out recently.
Marginalia.
Marginalia.
I interviewed her for the book.
Heather Jackson in Toronto.
She's wonderful.
She has a new one coming from Yale soon, in a couple of months, called Romantic Readers, a companion volume.
Books in the British Library, people reading in the Romantic era, and the impressions of their reading that they left.
Of course, when you talk about marginalia to librarians, they go crazy.
Oh, sure.
But that's why I love the provenance thing, because
in these cheap books I buy at the book fair sometimes.
Old marks, you know, you'll see in crayon, two dollars crossed out, one dollar under it crossed out, fifty cents crossed out.
I love that.
I do too.
Or all the names or who an old book plate or things that
Also, of course, the stuff that you shake out of them.
Well, the book is artifact.
I mean, this is really my fundamental interest of the book as object.
It's not just the content, which of course is what the exercise seems to be about, but how the book is... I tell the story often.
I may even write a children's book about this at some point, but at the Library of Congress they have a copy of Kirkham's Grammar, which is a self-help...
teach yourself how to read and write and type of a thing.
Not even a first edition.
If you saw it at the fair here, you wouldn't pay 25 cents for it.
Read to tatters.
The only distinguishing thing is the prior ownership signature of Abraham Lincoln.
And the fact that it's the earliest known book that has been in his hands, and it is the book that
is that when he arrived in New Salem, he walked eight miles to get the book.

If you handle it as I have and you feel the tingle, you know, from these pages, it could emerge the Gettysburg Address, the Emancipation Proclamation, and, you know, the feeling of that, the energy that comes from holding a book like that.
Yeah, yeah.
I thought that would make a pretty good kid's book, a little children's book.
Oh, yeah, it would.
Maybe my wife and I.
two weeks, two days, that I might work on.
So are you looking for anything special when you go, when you go looking for books, or is it serendipity?
No, it's totally, especially at the book fair.
But no, it's, I have, of course, I keep an eye on for certain books that I tend to really collect, in a sense.
James, anything, or Rilke, or Stein, or, there are a few people.
Wyndham Lewis or, oh, what's that, Malcolm Lowry.
When I was in Canada, I was busy getting Malcolm Lowry stuff.
But I'm not really trying to get first edition so much.
No, I understand.
I prefer that.
This is really my interest, too.
Right, I prefer that.
You know, it's nice, but— It's nice if you can— I want the text, because I use the text.
Do you write in your books?
Do you have annotations?
I used to.
I don't much anymore.
I use sticky little things.
But it's just simply, it's not that I have a particular objection to it or anything.
It's just that I don't have time.
I think the sticky things are good because it marks it for you.
Yeah.
Instead of flipping through the book to find where you... I know in a review of books,
from galleys or something, and I'll write in the thing, but then you have to put through it.
Yeah, well that's what I do.
And I use pretty big ones, and I can write on them, and then stick it there.
But I hope you keep those things, because I think they're very important.
They stay in the book, pretty much, and they go back up on the shelf.
There they are.
I tend to put books back before the damn fax checkers.
phone me and say, well, you didn't give us the fact check on such and such, and so I can go back and find what I quoted from.
Then I tag everything, I use it.
But, yeah, I don't, it's sheer chance.
So do you think a person who's not familiar with you, biographically, let's say, or has a knowledge of your writing, if this person were to come as an archaeologist, quote, through your
French room and your German room, and would they be able to get a sense of you as an individual and as a writer?
Uh, it might be a little hard because I collect a lot of writers that, and books that are not in my area, uh, or that I might not even be expected to like.
Um, uh, simply because I think my library ought to have them.

uh and uh so i i do and i'm and i'm surprising myself sometimes in actually using them uh but otherwise yeah because i i mean that's what i uh oh it's one of the autobiographical elements in the tunnel is the section uh where the narrator invokes the muse well i gave them
the invocation is a hundred pages long and he needs all the help he can get and it's books his muses are books and that's true for me and so calling on you know whoever to come to your aid so
And I like to keep books.
I never throw them away.
Never.
You don't discard anything?

No, because if I get a better copy of Hardy's Return of the Native, because my earlier one was a cheap paperback, it happened to be the first, one of the earliest paperbacks published, and it was one where I first read my first Hardy, I'm not going to give away, you know.
Well, I'd argue in one of my books that
Just because you get a new edition of the same, purportedly the same text, doesn't mean that they're the same.
No, it certainly doesn't.
There might be a really terrific introduction there that's useful to you, or the notes, whatever.
I mean, the book, again, as artifact, has different paratextual elements to it, as they say.
Right.
And oddly enough, I have quite a few books.
And it turned out to be...

damaged in the sense of misprinted uh signature repeated signature dropped i have a malcolm lowry in which that's true um now that ruins the value of the book i suspect but not for me not for you well i have a few pirated ones too very interesting um i found in shanghai a pirated edition this was when i was in the navy in the war
And I was stationed in Shanghai after the war, the Second World War, for a few months of Ulysses.
And it's just, it was published in San Francisco.
For what year?
Because the first is... There's no date on it.
No date.
But it is, it's clearly published.
Yeah, and it's clearly a porn thing because it has porn.
advertisements in the back, you know.
That's great.
And, you know, those are a few things.
After years of hunting in bookstoles, you have luck now and then.
But as I say, it's most popular.
I found the Fifty Cents, and I loved it.
Is it a copy of the
I don't mean the first, who cares, but the family Shakespeare, you know, Thomas Bolder, the original Bolderization of Shakespeare.
You know, you have to have that.
I do a little thing on Bolderism in my new book, and how so much of what young readers get, when you think of Rabelais, I mean, how Rabelais has been really
I guess Gulliver's Travels is a great example.
I mean, if you read all of that, there could be some arguments for, you know, censoring it.
Yeah, sure.
But the various versions that have been made from little readers all the way up to adult readers and how much we get through the filtration of a translator or an editor.
That's right.
And that seems to me what was driving you in the Rilke book.
You know, you really weren't happy with the translations that you were reading.
No, and I had them all there, in my library.
So I could stack them up right now.
You were almost grumpy about it.
Yeah.
It forced me to do it, because I was teaching them, and it forced me to start translating.
Because I was doing it, not because I'm a good translator, or that I could be better than they,
I wanted really to bring out more of the philosophical elements that I was teaching in the translation.
But it did.
It did drive me to try, you know.
And I also learned, of course, how difficult it is in a very practical way.
I try this, but I'm trying to work on it a little now.
I have a passion in the German canon.
Very difficult.
But I learn about, even though my translations are drizzly, I've read the poem when I get through.
I have some sense of what's going on.
I've gone through Elman's, if you mentioned Ulysses Joyce, he actually taught himself Norwegian, you know.
So he could read, uh, I know people.
I mean, it just drives me crazy because I'm such a bad linguist.
I have two friends.
One is a composer.
And every time he goes someplace, he's gay.
And he's always looking for good beaches with young men on them.
So he says, I'm going to go to Brazil.
Okay.
Popped in a Portuguese tapes in his car, and pretty soon he had picked up this thing by, with his ear, you know.
And he knows, I don't know how many languages that he had gotten.
I don't know how much he can read, but he can converse, at least enough to pick up young boys.
There you go.
Twenty languages.
But the other is a friend of mine who is, um, is, was a James scholar.
Oh, yes, I forgot one.
Oh, that's all right.
Go ahead.
I'm fine.
Uh, and this, uh, she, um, gets in for students' fable, so she learns the Italian.
Uh, and she got interested in Kierkegaard, so she learned Ganesh.
And now she's just finished a big novel that she's trying to get published, a translation from the Danish.
But she just, you know, it's amazing how, for me, impossible.
So tell me a little bit about, you said you were in the Navy, and did you have a sense of the arc of what your life was going to... No, I knew what I wanted to do.
I mean...
I knew I wanted to write, and I knew that what I wanted to write would not support me.
I knew also I didn't want to be in an English department at any cost.
I generally don't get along with English departments.
And I love philosophy, so I did want to go into philosophy.
And that's about it.
I mean, I didn't have any.
And this is at about the age of what?
Well, that decision was made when I was in high school.
I was sixteen or seventeen.
I had one advantage over some people.
I had a clear sense, because it was obvious, but I had a clear sense of what I wanted to do very early on.
I remember Mary, my wife who was an architect, she bounced from here to there and
She has very many skills.
When you only have one, it makes it easy.
And I, so I knew that.
The Navy was just a huge lengthy interruption in education.
And I got into the academy where I wanted to be, and I've been there ever since.
And of course it's
It's an incredibly annoying place, but it's better than anywhere else I can imagine.
And it's a day job, as they say.
Oh, yeah.
I haven't had that luxury, in fact.
I have just been invited by the Yale University Press to write a centennial history of the press.
Oh.
And I've never written for University Press before, to me.
And I'm going to meet with them next week, in fact.
Well, if you're there.
And you happen to run into a young woman named Michelle Comey, K-O-M-I-E.
She's a wonderful young woman.
She's one of the editors there now, and she worked at the International Writers' Center here.
She was on my staff for a couple years before she went off to Yale.
Introduce yourself, and she's terrific.
Young.
I think I'm going to do it.
Why not?
Sure.
This is so alien to me.
The copy deadline is the end of next year.
I said, so when's the pub date?
They said, 2008.
I said, two years?
Yeah.
I mean, you ought to have longer than the pub.
It takes to print it.
I mean, yeah, really.
But I guess that's the way it works.
academic publishing.
I mean, I just turned in a manuscript for my new book a couple weeks ago, and it'll be out in December, you know.
Yeah, well, I just finished one and went to Knopf, and it'll be out in spring, early spring.
Right now?
Yeah.
Oh, wonderful.
What's the title?
Temple of Texts.
Oh, fantastic.
So, I mean, I just, it moved along.
Yeah.
Whereas, in an academic thing, everything takes forever.
Uh, and that's because there's no, no.
I mean, they assume the book is, you know, eternally irrelevant, you know, and it doesn't matter.
And they really need to assure themselves that you've had it right, I guess.
Oh, yeah.
And it's anonymous, so you don't know who's nitpicking.
But they know you, and that's the trouble.
Oh yeah, and if they like you, it's one thing.
If they don't, I've always resisted it.
My wife loves Yale University Press and likes Yale, and it's not a lot of money, but it will serve me well between this book and the next one I want to write, waiting to see how the new one does.
It's like baseball.
What kind of a year did you have last year?
Yeah, that's right, yeah.
I have a lot of confidence in this book that's coming out this fall.
I might—I'm going to shut this off a second.
I don't have to trans— Invitations to conferences that were largely translation problems and stuff.
So I got to meet a number of translators to whom I am totally indebted, and that was fun.
And I really enjoyed those conferences.
I usually don't like these things.
And it was, and I met him.
I've met now a great many of the translators I adore.
So I'm thinking this little conversation might work in there.
And I've got a wonderful editor at Harper's who will allow me to do this.
Oh.
He'll let me do stuff with the manuscript.
I can't really do it when the galleys come back.
You know, I'm not tinkering.
No.
Things like that.
I've already told them I'll be giving them 2,000 more awards, so what's the difference between 2,000 and 3,000, right?
Yeah, right.
That's what I think.
We'll see what happens.
But if you think about this whole idea, if we could just kind of enter a little bit of conversation on so much of what we get of the Western canon or the great books,
It comes by way of someone else's translation, someone else's taste.
Oh, yeah, yeah.
And you discuss that to some extent in that book.
Yeah.
Well, again, of course, one is aware, especially if you try to translate anything yourself, of how much is lost.
I mean, that's—and it's famous, and everybody knows about it.
But, good heavens,
There are people who, and I think Pound was one, whose best work depends on bouncing off another text.
Really?
And I think it shows up in his response.
He does then translate things that are very often not literal in any sense.
But that is his real source of inspiration for his own work.
And a lot of the translators, some of them are classics of the early Rabelais translator and people like that.
Or somebody like Thomas Hobbes' translation of Thucydides.
Now Thucydides is suddenly a renaissance
Yeah, but he had an agenda.
Forbes had an agenda.
Oh, sure.
Well, they all do.
Especially an agenda.
But the language is amazing.
Now, it isn't facilities anymore, but it is a fascinating thing.
But there are other people, like William Weaver's translations, for instance, of Calvino.
Those are gorgeous.
Weaver's fabulous.
He's just terrific, or robust.
Um, and one of my favorite Latin American writers, I can't read Spanish, and I couldn't read this difficult stuff anyhow, I did know some.
Um, uh, Jose Lima is, is incredibly complicated.
Uh, and he did Lima's novel so beautifully in the sense of how it reads in English.
Now, maybe
It's not Lima's book anymore, but who cares?
It's a great book in English.
I'd just like you to follow up on a phrase you use, pound, his best stuff is bouncing off texts.
What do you mean by that?
Well, I think he looks at the texts and he's reading the courtier poets, I mean the troubadour poets, and

he's or he's moving off of some early thing which the earlier the better or the the the language even further away uh and the ideas uh spark his real poetic gifts and then he starts to write the poem that that he he is is encouraged to write by this thing in the other i felt that tug myself um
The best translations I've done of Rilke poems were done for my novel, where I had a different problem.
Namely, I had to translate a couple of, about four, of Rilke's poems as my narrator would have translated them.
Wonderful, yeah.
So, I felt freer.

suddenly instead of trying to be so faithful to the poem I could just sort of screw around and I think I did a better job and and I can understand that feeling and some of the most famous passages in the cantos or our translations the seafarer stuff is this marvelous
And he was a person like this, of course, who was constantly digging into books and getting his ideas and phrasing.
And I can carry, I know I can carry a phrase of, say, Ben Johnson's around for five years, waiting for something in my own work to try to capture what he did when he
moves from one idea to another is, oh, so wonderful.
And, you know, you're just wasting, waiting, waiting, waiting.
You're killing me with this, because I like using epigraphs for all my chapters.
Uh-huh.
And it kind of makes it, I write a little bit about commonplace books.
Oh, yeah.
So it's kind of a little exercise in putting quotes up there, but as you say, you'll carry a quote around.
I'll carry it around.

I was first looking into Chapman's Homer for a decade, and then when I was writing this chapter on translation, I said, I have to use the whole sonnet, much of my travel in the realms of the world and many goodly isles and kingdoms seen.
He's talking about reading a translation, Chapman's translation of Homer.
That's right.
Not just those two lines, use the whole sonnet.
I think the only danger of these translations is that somebody may get too great a notion that they're reading the original.
Yeah.
Well, Brea had a very good point.
He said, one of the big paradoxes is that the works themselves in the original are eternal.
They're, you know, Cervantes, but it is fresh today in the original as it ever has been.
And yet we need, every generation seems to need a new translation.
New version.
Because the translations date very quickly.
That's right.
Very interesting, isn't it?
Yeah.
Well, I think the point of Borges' wonderful piece, Pierre Menard, because that crazy idea that Pierre Menard is going to write Cervantes over

himself word for word the way but cervantes did but it's going to be pierre menard's thing is simply a metaphor for each reader because each reader reads every word of the original essay in spanish for boys each word
Where does Borges articulate this?
This is in a collection called Fiction.
I haven't had that.
Okay, good.
And it's called Pierre Menard, the author of Don Quixote.
And it's a wonderful piece on translation and reading.
Because, he says, Pierre Menard's version, which is word-for-word the same as Cervantes wrote, which, if you were reading Spanish,
You would read every word Cervantes wrote, but, he says, the references to Nietzsche in Pierre Menard's version is so much profounder than in Cervantes.
And, of course, the whole idea is that you bring to it all kinds of other things, and you see existentialist feelings here and back there that are
I can't wait to get to this when I get home.
It's a wonderful piece.
He's terrific on that, I think.
I love the Library of Babel, too.
It's wonderful.
I used an excerpt from that as the epigrack of my Patience and Fortune book.
Oh, yeah.
He was very funny.
He came here, and I was supposed to
introduce him at the chapel.
And so the day before, we had lunch.
And apparently he is very interested in etymology of people's names.
And so he said, gas, gas, what is that?
What is the meaning of that?
And I said, well, it's just, it's German, it's gasa.
And it's just alley, it really means alley.
And he just beamed.
And he said, oh, well, you know, my name comes from Burgos, city.
Ah, he says, I'm a city.
And you're an alley.
And summed up the literary situation.
That's wonderful.
Yeah.

I've got a nice profile of Robert Coles in my new book where he talks about, and he's the one who pioneers this whole concept of teaching medical students literature, the idea of making them better positions, but he's in his course with the Harvard students called Guilt 105, and he teaches Dorothy Day,
And the Elie Wiesel book he has them read is Night, so it's Night and Day.
They call that stage of the course Night and Day.
It's kind of cool.
Yeah, it is.
He's a lot of fun.
I can't wait to get this into ... There's a woman picking me up about 10.30, and if you don't mind, I always carry a camera with me, but I came here from the University of Wisconsin, and the camera
is at home, and this woman who's picking me up is bringing a camera.
Would you mind if I snap a couple of pictures of you?
Oh, no.
No problem.
Because I really would like to do that.
Oh, sure.
We do have something for you.
Oh, Mary's burning it.
A CD with all of Catherine's, our daughter's stuff about books.
Oh, fabulous.
Maybe I can do something.
Well, I don't know about that, but you might be curious.
Well, I'm writing a column for this new magazine called Fine Books and Collections, and it just started, and I'm looking for fresh ideas of things to write about, and one never knows, do one.
That's right.
Speaking of translations, there's this new press.
I don't know if you've seen Archipelago books or not.
I haven't.
And I've got one right here, just a new one, but they do nothing but translation.
Oh, really?
And they're really nice.
It's a nice trap.
I get it.
On their boards, whatever you call it.
Oh, wow.
It's one of them.
And I really love the way they did this.
Let me just write some of this stuff down.
One of the photographs that a friend of mine, he lives right across the street.
He's a terrific photographer.
Went to Paris.
to photograph the Rodin things.
And this on the wall here is one of his photographs of Rodin.
In fact, I saw this Eastman.
There's a lot of pictures for you, isn't it?
Yes.
We're doing a—with Ken Botnick, who's designing the book, we're doing a really expensive text of his stuff.
I'll check these out.
Where is Acapella, though?
It's in New York.
